member.name: T:InTheHand.Net.BluetoothAddress
member.summary: Represents a Bluetooth device address.

member.name: M:InTheHand.Net.BluetoothAddress.#ctor(System.Int64)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified address.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified address.
member.param: Address as 6 byte array.
member.exception: address passed was null (/Nothing).
address passed was not a 6 byte array.

member.name: M:InTheHand.Net.BluetoothAddress.TryParse(System.String,InTheHand.Net.BluetoothAddress@)
member.summary: Converts the string representation of an address to it's equivalent. A return value indicates whether the operation succeeded.
member.param: A string containing an address to convert.

When this method returns, contains the equivalent to the address contained in s, if the conversion succeeded, or null (Nothing in Visual Basic) if the conversion failed. The conversion fails if the s parameter is null or is not of the correct format.
member.returns: true if s is a valid Bluetooth address; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:InTheHand.Net.BluetoothAddress.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: Converts the string representation of a Bluetooth address to a new instance.
member.param: A string containing an address to convert.
member.returns: New instance.
member.remarks: Address must be specified in hex format optionally separated by the colon or period character e.g. 000000000000, 00:00:00:00:00:00 or 00.00.00.00.00.00.
member.exception: bluetoothString is null.
bluetoothString is not a valid IrDA address.

member.name: T:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName
member.summary: Defines configuration option names for the class.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.Authenticate
member.summary: On connected socket, triggers authentication. On not connected socket, forces authentication on connection. For incoming connection this means that connection is rejected if authentication cannot be performed.
member.remarks: The optval and optlen parameters are ignored; however, Winsock implementation on Windows CE requires optlen to be at least 4 and optval to point to at least an integer datum.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.XPAuthenticate
member.summary: Toggles authentication under Windows XP.
member.remarks: optlen=sizeof(ULONG), optval = &(ULONG)TRUE/FALSE

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.Encrypt
member.summary: On a connected socket, this command turns encryption on or off. On an unconnected socket, this forces encryption to be on or off on connection. For an incoming connection, this means that the connection is rejected if the encryption cannot be turned on.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.SetPin
member.summary: This sets or revokes PIN code to use with a connection or socket.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.SetLink
member.summary: This sets or revokes link key to use with a connection or peer device.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.GetLink
member.summary: Returns link key associated with peer Bluetooth device.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.XPMtu
member.summary: Get or set the default MTU on Windows XP.
member.remarks: optlen=sizeof(ULONG), optval = &mtu

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.SetMtu
member.summary: This sets default MTU (maximum transmission unit) for connection negotiation. While allowed for connected socket, it has no effect if the negotiation has already completed. Setting it on listening socket will propagate the value for all incoming connections.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.GetMtu
member.summary: Returns MTU (maximum transmission unit). For connected socket, this is negotiated value, for server (accepting) socket it is MTU proposed for negotiation on connection request.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.XPMtuMaximum
member.summary: Get or set the maximum MTU on Windows XP.
member.remarks: optlen=sizeof(ULONG), optval = &max. mtu

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.SetMtuMaximum
member.summary: This sets maximum MTU for connection negotiation. While allowed for connected socket, it has no effect if the negotiation has already completed. Setting it on listening socket will propagate the value for all incoming connections.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.GetMtuMaximum
member.summary: Returns maximum MTU acceptable MTU value for a connection on this socket. Because negotiation has already happened, has little meaning for connected socket.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.XPMtuMinimum
member.summary: Get or set the minimum MTU on Windows XP.
member.remarks: optlen=sizeof(ULONG), optval = &min. mtu

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.SetMtuMinimum
member.summary: This sets minimum MTU for connection negotiation. While allowed for connected socket, it has no effect if the negotiation has already completed. Setting it on listening socket will propagate the value for all incoming connections.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.GetMtuMinimum
member.summary: Returns minimum MTU acceptable MTU value for a connection on this socket. Because negotiation has already happened, has little meaning for connected socket.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.SetXOnLimit
member.summary: This sets XON limit. Setting it on listening socket will propagate the value for all incoming connections.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.GetXOnLimit
member.summary: Returns XON limit for a connection. XON limit is only used for peers that do not support credit-based flow control (mandatory in the Bluetooth Core Specification version 1.1). When amount of incoming data received, but not read by an application for a given connection grows past this limit, a flow control command is sent to the peer requiring suspension of transmission.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.SetXOffLimit
member.summary: This sets XOFF limit. Setting it on listening socket will propagate the value for all incoming connections.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.GetXOffLimit
member.summary: Returns XOFF limit for a connection. XOFF limit is only used for peers that do not support credit-based flow control (mandatory in the Bluetooth Core Specification 1.1). If flow has been suspended because of buffer run-up, when amount of incoming data received, but not read by an application for a given connection falls below this limit, a flow control command is sent to the peer allowing continuation of transmission.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.SetSendBuffer
member.summary: Specifies maximum amount of data that can be buffered inside RFCOMM (this is amount of data before call to send blocks).

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.GetSendBuffer
member.summary: Returns maximum amount of data that can be buffered inside RFCOMM (this is amount of data before call to send blocks).

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.SetReceiveBuffer
member.summary: Specifies maximum amount of data that can be buffered for a connection. This buffer size is used to compute number of credits granted to peer device when credit-based flow control is implemented. This specifies the maximum amount of data that can be buffered.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Bluetooth.BluetoothSocketOptionName.GetReceiveBuffer
member.summary: Returns maximum amount of data that can be buffered for a connection. This buffer size is used to compute number of credits granted to peer device when credit-based flow control is implemented. This specifies the maximum amount of data that can be buffered.

member.name: T:InTheHand.Net.Sockets.IrDASocketOptionName
member.summary: Socket option constants to set IrDA specific connection modes, and get/set IrDA specific features.
member.remarks:
Socket option constants to set IrDA specific connection modes, and get/set IrDA specific features: for instance to set IrLMP mode, or get the maximum send size. Pass to and , along with optionLevel IrDASocketOptionLevel.; see the examples below.
New in v1.5.51015
member.example:
For instance, where cli is an instance of . In VB.NET, to set IrLMP mode (IrLptMode).
cli.Client.SetSocketOption(IrDASocketOptionLevel.Irlmp, _ IrDASocketOptionName.IrLptMode, _ 1) 'representing true; can use True itself in FXv2.
In C#, to retrieve the maximum send size.
int maxSendSize = (int)cli.Client.GetSocketOption( IrDASocketOptionLevel.Irlmp, IrDASocketOptionName.SendPduLength);

member.summary: Sets an entry in the local IAS (Information Access Service) database.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Sockets.IrDASocketOptionName.SendPduLength
member.summary: Retrieve the maximum send size when using IrLMP directly (). IrLMP requires sent data to fit in one frame.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Sockets.IrDASocketOptionName.ExclusiveMode
member.remarks: Returns an error on all tested platforms. Boolean

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.Sockets.IrDASocketOptionName.IrLptMode
member.summary: Sets IrLMP mode, disabling TinyTP. Used for instance when printing with IrLPT.
member.remarks: On Windows NT platforms at least, is ignored on server-side sockets. Boolean

member.name: T:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode
member.summary: Specifies the status codes returned for an Object Exchange (OBEX) operation.
member.remarks: OBEX codes are directly related to their HTTP equivalents - see .

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.Final
member.summary: Applied to another code to indicate this is the only response or final response in a series.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.Continue
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 100. Continue indicates that the client can continue with its request.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.OK
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 200. OK indicates that the request succeeded and that the requested information is in the response. This is the most common status code to receive.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.Created
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 201. Created indicates that the request resulted in a new resource created before the response was sent.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.Accepted
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 202. Accepted indicates that the request has been accepted for further processing.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.NonAuthorativeInformation
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 203. NonAuthoritativeInformation indicates that the returned metainformation is from a cached copy instead of the origin server and therefore may be incorrect.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.NoContent
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 204. NoContent indicates that the request has been successfully processed and that the response is intentionally blank.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.ResetContent
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 205. ResetContent indicates that the client should reset (not reload) the current resource.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.PartialContent
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 206. PartialContent indicates that the response is a partial response as requested by a GET request that includes a byte range.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.MultipleChoices
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 300. MultipleChoices indicates that the requested information has multiple representations.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.MovedPermanently
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 301. MovedPermanently indicates that the requested information has been moved to the URI specified in the Location header. The default action when this status is received is to follow the Location header associated with the response.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.MovedTemporarily
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 302. Redirect indicates that the requested information is located at the URI specified in the Location header. The default action when this status is received is to follow the Location header associated with the response. When the original request method was POST, the redirected request will use the GET method.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.SeeOther
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 303. SeeOther automatically redirects the client to the URI specified in the Location header as the result of a POST. The request to the resource specified by the Location header will be made with a GET.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.NotModified
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 304. NotModified indicates that the client's cached copy is up to date. The contents of the resource are not transferred.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.UseProxy
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 305. UseProxy indicates that the request should use the proxy server at the URI specified in the Location header.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.BadRequest
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 400. BadRequest indicates that the request could not be understood by the server. BadRequest is sent when no other error is applicable, or if the exact error is unknown or does not have its own error code.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.Unauthorized
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 401. Unauthorized indicates that the requested resource requires authentication. The WWW-Authenticate header contains the details of how to perform the authentication.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.PaymentRequired
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 402. PaymentRequired is reserved for future use.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.Forbidden
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 403. Forbidden indicates that the server refuses to fulfill the request.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.NotFound
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 404. NotFound indicates that the requested resource does not exist on the server.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.MethodNotAllowed
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 405. MethodNotAllowed indicates that the request method (POST or GET) is not allowed on the requested resource.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.NotAcceptable
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 406. NotAcceptable indicates that the client has indicated with Accept headers that it will not accept any of the available representations of the resource.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.ProxyAuthenticationRequired
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 407. ProxyAuthenticationRequired indicates that the requested proxy requires authentication. The Proxy-authenticate header contains the details of how to perform the authentication.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.RequestTimeout
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 408. RequestTimeout indicates that the client did not send a request within the time the server was expecting the request.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.Conflict
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 409. Conflict indicates that the request could not be carried out because of a conflict on the server.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.Gone
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 410. Gone indicates that the requested resource is no longer available.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.LengthRequired
member.summary: Equivalent to HTTP status 411. LengthRequired indicates that the required Content-length header is missing.

member.name: F:InTheHand.Net.ObexStatusCode.PreconditionFailed

member.name: P:InTheHand.Net.Sockets.BluetoothClient.Authenticate
member.summary: Gets or sets the authentication state of the current connect or behaviour to use when connection is established.
member.remarks: For disconnected sockets, specifies that authentication is required in order for a connect or accept operation to complete successfully. Setting this option actively initiates authentication during connection establishment, if the two Bluetooth devices were not previously authenticated. The user interface for passkey exchange, if necessary, is provided by the operating system outside the application context. For outgoing connections that require authentication, the connect operation fails with WSAEACCES if authentication is not successful. In response, the application may prompt the user to authenticate the two Bluetooth devices before connection. For incoming connections, the connection is rejected if authentication cannot be established and returns a WSAEHOSTDOWN error.

member.name: P:InTheHand.Net.Sockets.BluetoothClient.Encrypt
member.summary: On unconnected sockets, enforces encryption to establish a connection. Encryption is only available for authenticated connections. For incoming connections, a connection for which encryption cannot be established is automatically rejected and returns WSAEHOSTDOWN as the error. For outgoing connections, the connect function fails with WSAEACCES if encryption cannot be established. In response, the application may prompt the user to authenticate the two Bluetooth devices before connection.

member.name: T:InTheHand.Net.Sockets.BluetoothListener
member.summary: Listens for connections from Bluetooth network clients.
member.remarks: The class provides simple methods that listen for and accept incoming connection requests in blocking synchronous mode. You can use either a or a to connect with a

members.member:
Initializes a new instance of the class.
----
Initializes a new instance of the class to listen on the specified service identifier.
The Bluetooth service to listen for.
An SDP record is published on successful to advertise the server. A generic record is created, containing the essential ServiceClassIdList and ProtocolDescriptorList attributes. The specified service identifier is inserted into the former, and the RFCOMM Channel number that the server is listening on is inserted into the latter. See the Bluetooth SDP specification for details on the use and format of SDP records.
If a SDP record with more elements is required, then use one of the other constructors that takes an SDP record as a byte array, e.g. . The format of the generic record used here is shown there also.
Call the method to begin listening for incoming connection attempts.

member.name: M:InTheHand.Net.Sockets.BluetoothListener.#ctor(System.Guid,System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class to listen on the specified service identifier, publishing the specified SDP record.
member.param: The Bluetooth service to listen for.
Prepared SDP Record to publish.
The index in the byte array where the RFCOMM Channel Number that the server is listening on is to be placed.

remarks.note: The constructors taking the SDP record explicitly (as a byte array) should only be used if a specialized SDP record is required. For instance when using one of the standard profiles. Otherwise use one of the other constructors e.g. which create a generic SDP Record from the specified service identifier.
remarks.para: Any useful SDP record will include a ProtocolDescriptor element containing the RFCOMM Channel number that the server is listening on. The record supplied in the parameter should contain such an element. On successful , the RFCOMM Channel number that the protocol stack has assigned to the server is retrieved, and copied into the service record before it is published. The indicates the location of the respective byte in the byte array.

member.name: M:InTheHand.Net.Sockets.BluetoothListener.AcceptSocket
member.summary: Creates a new socket for a connection.
member.remarks:
AcceptSocket is a blocking method that returns a that you can use to send and receive data. If you want to avoid blocking, use the method to determine if connection requests are available in the incoming connection queue.
The returned is initialized with the address and channel number of the remote device. You can use any of the Send and Receive methods available in the class to communicate with the remote device. When you are finished using the , be sure to call its method. If your application is relatively simple, consider using the method rather than the AcceptSocket method. provides you with simple methods for sending and receiving data over a network in blocking synchronous mode.
member.returns: A used to send and receive data.
member.exception: Listener is stopped.

member.name: T:InTheHand.Net.Sockets.IrDAClient
member.summary: Makes connections to services on peer IrDA devices.

remarks.para: Makes connections to services on peer IrDA devices. It allows discovery of all devices in range, then a connection can be made to the required service on the chosen peer. Or, given just the service name a connection will be made to an arbitrary peer. This is most useful when it is expected that there will be only one device in rangeas is often the case.

It can be used with both the full and Compact frameworks, and can be used as a replacement for the latter's built-in version simply by changing the referenced namespace and assembly. It also has features extra to those in the CF's version. For instance, following the pattern of in framework version 2, it provides access to the underlying via a Client property. This is particularly useful as it allows setting socket options, for instance IrCOMM Cooked mode with option .

There a number of well-known services, a few are listed here.
Service description Service Name, Protocol type
OBEX file transfer OBEX:IrXfer, (TinyTP)
OBEX general OBEX, (TinyTP)
Printing IrLPT, IrLMP mode
IrCOMM e.g. to modems IrDA:IrCOMM, IrCOMM 9-Wire/Cooked mode
The modes required by the last two are set by socket option, as noted for IrCOMM above.
Of course the library also includes specific OBEX protocol support, both client and server, see etc.

member.example:
Example code to connect to a IrCOMM service would be as follows.
Public Shared Sub Main() Dim cli As New IrDAClient ' Set IrCOMM Cooked/9-wire mode. cli.Client.SetSocketOption(IrDASocketOptionLevel.IrLmp, _ IrDASocketOptionName.NineWireMode, _ 1) ' equivalent to 'True' ' Connect cli.Connect("IrDA:IrCOMM") ' Connected, now send and receive e.g. by using the ' NetworkStream returned by cli.GetStream ... End Sub

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class and connects to the specified service name.

remarks.para: This is equivalent to calling the default constructor followed by .

As noted the connection will be made to an arbitrary peer. This is most useful when it is expected that there will be only one device in range — as is often the case. If a connection is to be made to a particular remote peer, then use the
overload.
Infrared connections are made by specifying a Service Name, which can be any value provided the participating devices refer the same name.

member.param: A containing the service name to connect to.

member.name: M:InTheHand.Net.Sockets.IrDAClient.Connect(System.String)
member.summary: Forms a connection to the specified service on an arbitrary peer.
member.remarks: As noted the connection will be made to an arbitrary peer. This is most useful when it is expected that there will be only one device in range — as is often the case. If a connection is to be made to a particular remote peer, then use .
member.param: The Service Name to connect eg "OBEX". In the very uncommon case where a connection is to be made to a specific LSAP-SEL (port number), then use the form "LSAP-SELn", where n is an integer.

members.member:
Returns the used to send and receive data.
- The underlying NetworkStream. -
GetStream returns a NetworkStream that you can use to send and receive data. The NetworkStream class inherits from the class, which provides a rich collection of methods and properties used to facilitate network communications.
You must call the method, or one of its overloads, first, or the GetStream method will throw an InvalidOperationException. After you have obtained the NetworkStream, call the
method to send data to the remote host. Call the method to receive data arriving from the remote host. Both of these methods block until the specified operation is performed. You can avoid blocking on a read operation by checking the property. A true value means that data has arrived from the remote host and is available for reading. In this case, Read is guaranteed to complete immediately. If the remote host has shutdown its connection, Read will immediately return with zero bytes.
Closing the NetworkStream closes the connection. Similarly Closing, Disposing, or the finalization of the IrDAClient Disposes the NetworkStream. This is new behaviour post 2.0.60828.0.
If you receive a SocketException, use SocketException.ErrorCode to obtain the specific error code. After you have obtained this code, you can refer to the Windows Sockets version 2 API error code documentation in MSDN for a detailed description of the error.
-
The is not connected to a remote host.
The IrDAClient has been closed.
